text: The Song of Deborah and Barak
And Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang on that day:
“When long hair hangs loosely in Israel,
when the people willingly offer themselves,
bless Yahweh!
Hear, O kings! Give ear, O princes!
I will sing to Yahweh;
I will sing praise to Yahweh,
the God of Israel.
Yahweh, when you went down from Seir,
when you marched from the region of Edom,
the earth trembled, the heavens poured down,
the clouds poured down water.
The mountains trembled\f + \fr 5:5 \ft Or “quaked” \f* before Yahweh,
this Sinai, at the presence of Yahweh, the God of Israel.
“In the days of Shamgar son of Anath,
in the days of Jael, the caravans had ceased,
⸤the travelers⸥,\f + \fr 5:6 \ft Literally “the ones walking on the paths” \f* ⸤they kept to the byways⸥.\f + \fr 5:6 \ft Literally “they went \fq on the \ft crooked roads” \f*
The warriors\f + \fr 5:7 \ft Others interpret this word as referring to the “rural dwellers” \f* ceased;
they failed to appear in Israel,
until I,\f + \fr 5:7 \ft Or “you” \f* Deborah, arose;
I\f + \fr 5:7 \ft Or “you” \f* arose \add as\add* a mother in Israel.
God chose new \add leaders\add*,\f + \fr 5:8 \ft ESV, NRSV translate “when new gods were chosen” \f*
then war \add was at the\add* gates;
a small shield or a spear was not seen
among forty thousand in Israel.
My heart \add goes out\add* to the commanders of Israel,
those offering themselves willingly among the people;
bless Yahweh!
The riders of white female donkeys,
\add those\add* sitting on saddle blankets,
and \add those\add* going on \add the\add* way, talk about it!
At the sound of \add those\add* dividing\f + \fr 5:11 \ft Meaning uncertain; other translations have “archers” (Tanakh), “musicians” (ESV, NRSV) or “singers” (NIV, HCSB) \f* \add the sheep\add*
among the watering places,
there they will recount the righteous deeds of Yahweh,
the righteous deeds for his warriors\f + \fr 5:11 \ft Hebrew “warrior” \f* in Israel.
Then the people of Yahweh went down to the gates.
“Wake up, wake up, Deborah!
Wake up, wake up, sing a song!
Get up, Barak!
Take captive your captives, O son of Abinoam.
Then \add the\add* remnant went down to \add the\add* nobles;
the people of Yahweh went down for him\f + \fr 5:13 \ft Hebrew “me” \f* against \add the\add* mighty.
From Ephraim \add is\add* their root into Amalek,
after you, Benjamin, with your family;
from Makir \add the\add* commanders went down,
and from Zebulun \add those\add* carrying \add the\add* scepter
of \add the\add* military commander.
And the chiefs\f + \fr 5:15 \ft Hebrew “my chiefs”; ancient translations read “the chiefs” \f* in Issachar \add were\add* with Deborah;
and Issachar likewise \add was with\add* Barak;
into the valley ⸤he was sent to get him from behind⸥.\f + \fr 5:15 \ft Literally “he was sent at his feet” \f*
Among the clans of Reuben
\add were\add* great ⸤decisions of the heart⸥.\f + \fr 5:15 \ft Or “thoughts of the heart” \f*
Why do you sit among the sheepfolds,
to hear \add the\add* calling sounds of the herds?
For the clans of Reuben,
\add there were\add* great searchings of the heart.
Gilead has remained\f + \fr 5:17 \ft Or “stayed” \f* beyond the Jordan.
Why did Dan dwell as a foreigner \add with\add* ships?
Asher sat at \add the\add* coast of \add the\add* waters,
and by his coves he has been settling down.
Zebulun \add is\add* a people who scorned death,
and Naphtali, on the heights of \add the\add* field.
“The kings came, they fought;
then the kings of Canaan fought;
at Taanach by the waters of Megiddo,
they got no plunder in silver.
The stars fought from heaven;
from their courses they fought against Sisera.
The wadi\f + \fr 5:21 \ft A valley that is dry most of the year, but contains a stream during the rainy season \f* torrent of Kishon swept them away,
the raging wadi torrent,
the wadi torrent of Kishon.
March on, my soul, \add with\add* strength!
“Then the hooves of the horse beat loudly,
because of galloping, galloping of his stallions.
‘Curse Meroz,’ says the angel of Yahweh;
‘curse bitterly its inhabitants,
because they did not come to the help of Yahweh,
to the help of Yahweh against the mighty.’
“Most blessed of women is Jael,
the wife of Heber the Kenite;
most blessed is she of women among tent dwellers.
He asked for water, \add and\add* she gave milk;
in a drinking bowl for nobles, she brought curds.
She reached out her hand to the peg,
and her right hand for the workman’s hammer;
and she struck Sisera, crushed his head,
and she shattered and pierced his temple.
Between her feet he sank, he fell, he lay.
Between her feet he sank down, he fell;
Where he sank down, there he fell—⸤dead⸥.\f + \fr 5:27 \ft Literally “devastated” \f*
“Through the window she looked down;
the mother of Sisera cried out through the lattice,
‘Why is his chariot delayed in coming?
Why do the hoof beats\f + \fr 5:28 \ft Or “steps” \f* of his chariot tarry?’
The wisest of her ladies answer her;
she also answers the question herself:
‘Are they not finding and dividing the plunder?
⸤A bedmate or two bedmates for every man⸥;\f + \fr 5:30 \ft Literally “a womb, two wombs for \fq head \ft of \fq every \ft man” \f*
colorful garments for Sisera,
plunder of colorful garments,\f + \fr 5:30 \ft Hebrew “garment” \f*
beautifully finished colorful garments,
on the neck of the plunderer?’
So may all your enemies perish, O Yahweh,
but those who love him are like the rising sun at its brightest.”
And the land had rest for forty years.
